quote: Tetapi sebaliknya pakcik tu mempunyai kefahaman yang lebih mendalam dengan situasi tu. Maruah ketika memberi atau membantu.
content:
Dapatkan berita yang paling viral setiap hari:






Seorang lelaki warga emas telah membuka mata dan menjadi inspirasi ramai orang lepas dia buat satu kebaikan. Meskipun tindakan tu tak sebesar mana, tetapi ia berjaya mengubah cara orang lain berfikir.
Menurut Coconuts, tweet seorang wanita viral baru-baru ni menceritakan tentang pakcik dari Filipina tu yang berhati mulia sebab bantu seseorang yang memerlukan.
Apa yang membuatkan wanita tu dan ramai lagi netizen lain tersentuh is because pakcik berkenaan bantu guna cara ‘halus’! Macam mana tu?
“Malam ni (8 Oktober), seorang lelaki dekat luar kedai runcit duduk di kaki lima sambil mengira duitnya. 
Dia asyik menggaru kepala. 
Dia tanya kepada guard, ‘berapa jumlahnya?’
Guard tu menjawab, dan dia tak berkata apa apa. Cuma terus mengira (duit).”

Menurut Celina, kejadian tu berlaku di kedai runcit dekat Boni, Bandar Mandaluyong dan dia sendiri menjadi saksi bagaimana pakcik tu membuka matanya dengan kebaikan yang dilakukan.
Seorang lelaki yang berada dekat kedai runcit tu dikatakan tidak cukup duit untuk membayar susu tepung. So, pakcik tu berniat untuk membantu.
Meskipun duitnya tak banyak mana, dia tetap berusaha juga kira berapa banyak duit yang dia ada untuk bantu lelaki tersebut.
Ketika kejadian jam 7.30 malam tu, Celina beritahu yang dia berniat untuk membayarkan bil lelaki tersebut tapi menurut guard, lelaki tu sendiri menolak.
“Saya mahu berikan wang dan beritahu guard untuk berikan padanya (lelaki dalam kedai runcit). 
Guard tu berkata, ‘Dia takkan amik, puan. Saya dah cuba beri (duit) pada dia tadi.”
Gambar hiasan
Disebabkan lelaki tersebut berkeras taknak terima duit, pakcik tu dapat satu idea untuk membantu. Dia minta izin pada Celina untuk tolong berikan duit tu pada lelaki berkenaan. Nak tahu macam mana pakcik tu buat?
Lepas ambil duit dekat Celina, pakcik tu lipat not kertas tu dan berjalan ke arah lelaki tersebut, membongkok, sentuh belakang dia dan cakap,
(Duit) ini jatuh dari poket kamu.”
Sambil cakap tu, dia serahkan duit yang dia dah lipat tadi kepada lelaki tersebut. Tapi, lelaki tu berkata yang duit tu bukan milik dia. Pakcik tu balas,
Saya nampak (duit) ni (jatuh) dari (seluar) kamu. Kamu punya ni.”
Lelaki tu kemudian ambil duit tersebut dan ucap terima kasih sebelum bergegas masuk kedai runcit untuk bayar susu tepung yang nak dibeli. Celina yang nampak cara pakcik tu akui tersentuh.
“Pakcik tu pandang saya dan senyum. Hati saya tersentuh. Pakcik tu faham bahawa kita perlu ada maruah untuk membantu, itulah yang dia lakukan.”

quote: Ini kerana proses perundangan biasa memerlukan bukti yang jelas dengan kehadiran saksi ke mahkamah untuk keterangan serta diperiksa balas oleh peguam tertuduh.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR – Walaupun sebelum ini mendapat pelbagai tentangan terhadap akta-akta yang dianggap tidak demokratik dan menindas sehingga wujudnya keperluan untuk pemansuhan, namun kerajaan masih belum membuat keputusan keputusan mengenainya.
Malah menurut Menteri Dalam Negeri, Tan Sri Muhyiddin Yassin, pemansuhan akta-akta pencegahan itu tidak akan memberi sebarang jaminan keselamatan negara akan ‘kekal terjamin’ seperti sebelum ini.
Kata Muhyiddin, akta-akta seperti Akta Kesalahan Keselamatan (Langkah-Langkah Khas) 2012 (SOSMA), Akta Pencegahan Keganasan (POTA) dan Akta Pencegahan Jenayah 1959 sebenarnya membantu mengekalkan keselamatan negara seperti sekarang.
“Saya tidak dapat menjamin dengan menghapuskan akta-akta pencegahan ini, kita mampu mengekalkan keselamatan negara yang aman sebelum ini akan kekal.
“Saya berpendapat semua akta-akta ini sangat penting yang juga telah mendapat kelulusan Parlimen berdasarkan perlembagaan sebelum dikuatkuasakan selepas itu. Namun begitu, wujud keperluan untuk kita buat kajian tentang akta-akta ini,” katanya ketika sesi pertanyaan di Dewan Rakyat sebentar tadi.
Beliau mengulas pertanyaan Ahli Parlimen Petaling Jaya (PH), Maria Chin dan Ahli Parlimen Pontian (BN), Datuk Ahmad Maslan berhubung status serta keputusan kerajaan dalam mengekalkan atau memansuhkan akata-akta pencegahan itu kelak.
Jelas Muhyiddin, kebanyakan akta itu digubal di bawah Perkara 149 Perlembagan Persekutuan untuk membolehkan pihak berkuasa membawa penjenayah dan pengganas ke muka pengadilan tanpa proses perundangan biasa.
“Ini kerana proses perundangan biasa memerlukan bukti yang jelas dengan kehadiran saksi ke mahkamah untuk keterangan serta diperiksa balas oleh peguam tertuduh.
“Bagi kes-kes yang melibatkan keselamatan, keterangan yang melibatkan kesalahan keselamatan, keterangan boleh dari saksi berbentuk risikan dan tidak boleh didedahkan secara terbuka di mahkamah,” jelasnya.
Dalam pada itu Muhyiddin menambah, rata-rata umum terutamanya pemegang taruh yang sebelum ini merasakan akta-akta seperti SOSMA, POCA dan Pota sebenarnya zalim dan bersifat menindas hak asasi kemanusian.
“Oleh yang demikian, kerajaan kini sedang dalam proses kajian terakhir bagi tujuan penambahbaikan. Sebuah jawatankuasa khas yang dikenali sebagai ‘Jawatankuasa Teknikal Kajian Undang-Undang Berkait Keselamatan’ telah ditubuhkan untuk meniliti secara terperinci.
“Antara yang dalam proses kajian ketika ini untuk tujuan tambahbaik akta-akta ini termasuk tempoh tahanan yang dilihat sangat panjang, kuasa polis yang sangat luas sehingga salahguna kuasa serta semakan kehakiman yang terhad.
“Kita juga sudah berada pada tahap akhir sebelum laporan kajian ini diserahkan kepada Jabatan Negara sebelum ke Jemaah Menteri dan ke Parlimen, saya jangka jika bukan sidang ini, mungkin sebelum penghujung Mac tahun depan,” ujarnya. –
Sebelum ini, Pakatan Harapan menyenaraikan 10 akta dan peruntukan undang-undang yang akan dimansuhkan sekiranya menjadi kerajaan.
Antara akta yang disenaraikan ialah Akta Hasutan 1948, Akta Pencegahan Jenayah 1959, Akta Mesin Cetak dan Penerbitan 1984, hukuman gantung mandatori, Akta Komunikasi dan Multimedia, Akta Kesalahan keselamatan Langkah-langkah Khas 2012 (Sosma);Akta Perhimpunan Aman 2012 dan Pota. –MalaysiaGazette

quote: Mangsa menunggang motosikal dari arah Pulau Pinang menuju ke Sungai Petani.
content:
GEORGETOWN - Seorang pemuda maut apabila gagal mengawal motosikal ditunggangnya lalu melanggar belakang sebuah kereta di Lebuhraya Utara Selatan tengahari semalam.

Ketua Polis Daerah Seberang Perai Utara (SPU), Assisten Komisioner Noorzainy Mohd Noor berkata, mangsa Muhammad Amirulzamir Md Isa, 24 disahkan meninggal dunia ketika dirawat di Hospital Seberang Jaya pada petang hari kejadian. Menurutnya, bedah siasat ke atas mayat mangsa mendapati, punca kematian adalah disebabkan kecederaan parah di kepala akibat kemalangan jalan raya.

"Mangsa berasal dari Permatang Damar Laut, Bayan Lepas dan merupakan pekerja kilang. "Siasatan mendapati, mangsa mempunyai lesen memandu dan lesen kenderaan bermotornya masih dalam tempoh," katanya ketika dihubungi hari ini. Beliau berkata, mangsa disahkan meninggal dunia pada jam 5 petang dan bedah siasat dijalankan pada jam 7.20 malam. "Mangsa menunggang motosikal dari arah Pulau Pinang menuju ke Sungai Petani. "Kejadian berlaku pada jam 12.06 tengahari semalam di KM124.8 Lebuhraya Utara Selatan apabila motosikal mangsa terlanggar belakang sebuah kereta yang mengalami kerosakan enjin," katanya. Tambahnya, pemandu kereta berkenaan memberhentikan kenderaannya di lorong kecemasan dan telah memaparkan papan isyarat kecemasan. "Namun, mangsa yang gagal mengelak telah melanggar belakang kereta tersebut menyebabkan dia cedera parah dan motosikalnya rosak teruk di bahagian hadapan," katanya. Pemandu kereta yang berusia 45 tahun tidak mengalami kecederaan. "Pemandu kereta yang berasal dari Sungai Petani, Kedah didapati tidak mempunyai lesen memandu dan lesen kenderaan motornya telah tamat tempoh. "Siasatan kes masih dijalankan," katanya.

quote: Penemuan survey ini sentiasa dinantikan kerajaan dan penganalisis untuk menilai kemajuan negara terutama berkaitan agihan pendapatan yang dinikmati rakyat.
content:
IPOH - Jabatan Perangkaan Malaysia (JPM) Perak sedang melaksanakan Survey Pendapatan, Perbelanjaan Isi Rumah (HIES) dan Kemudahan Asas (BA) 2019 bermula Januari hingga Disember tahun ini.

Pengarahnya, Rafliza Ramli berkata, survey berkenaan amat penting bagi mengumpul maklumat taburan pendapatan dan pola perbelanjaan isi rumah termasuk mengenal pasti golongan sasar seperti isi rumah B40 dan miskin. Beliau berkata, hasil survey itu akan digunakan oleh kerajaan dalam menyediakan dan memantau Rancangan Malaysia.

"Penemuan survey ini sentiasa dinantikan kerajaan dan penganalisis untuk menilai kemajuan negara terutama berkaitan agihan pendapatan yang dinikmati rakyat. "Bagi tujuan pelaksanaan survey HIES pada tahun ini, dianggarkan sejumlah lebih 7,000 tempat kediaman terpilih di Perak meliputi semua daerah pentadbiran akan dilawati," katanya kepada Sinar Harian dalam satu pertemuan di Pejabat Jabatan Perangkaan Perak, di sini. Turut sama dalam pertemuan itu, Timbalan Pengarah JPM Perak, Maslina Samsudin, Penolong Pengarah Jabatan Perangkaan Perak, Nur Aizatul Hajar Abdul Kadar dan Mohd Damanhuri Abdul Aziz. Rafliza berkata, sehubungan itu, pihaknya mengharapkan kerjasama daripada masyarakat untuk memberikan maklumat yang tepat kepada Jabatan Perangkaan Malaysia. Katanya, orang ramai tidak perlu bimbang dengan kehadiran pegawai perangkaan yang akan memperkenalkan diri bersama Kad Kuasa pengenalan Pegawai dan Surat Pemakluman pelaksanaan Survey Pendapatan Perbelanjaan Isi Rumah dan Kemudahan Asas, 2019 serta memakai vest Jabatan Perangkaan Malaysia. "Responden atau orang awam boleh menghubungi pejabat Jabatan Perangkaan Perak untuk mendapatkan pengesahan selain melayari portal www.dosm.gov.my bagi mengetahui maklumat lanjut mengenai survey ini. "Maklumat-maklumat yang dikumpul oleh pegawai Jabatan Perangkaan Malaysia adalah sulit dan hanya digunakan bagi tujuan perangkaan kerana tertakluk kepada peruntukan di bawah Akta Perangkaan 1965 (disemak 1989)," katanya. Menurut Rafliza, pihaknya sedang membuat hebahan dan pemakluman kepada orang ramai berhubung pelaksanaan survey ini termasuk melalui Majlis Pengurusan Komuniti Kampung (MPKK).

quote: Cucu mangsa yang bimbang keadaan itu kemudiannya bertindak mencari neneknya dan menemui basikal kepunyaan mangsa berhampiran Sungai Langat.
content:
Wanita warga emas ditemui lemas akibat tekanan perasaan




AHMAD SHAHERMAN SHAMSURI
30 November 2018 4:53 PM


KUALA LANGAT - Seorang wanita warga emas dipercayai mengalami tekanan jiwa ditemui mati selepas dipercayai terjun ke dalam Sungai Langat berhampiran Jambatan Telok Datok, Banting di sini petang semalam.

Mayat, Ang Siew, 74, ditemui dalam keadaan tertiarap pukul 1.10 petang di tengah Sungai Langat selepas air surut.
Ketua Polis Daerah Kuala Langat, Superintendan Azizan Tukiman berkata, sebelum kejadian cucu mangsa berusia 17 tahun menyatakan neneknya itu telah keluar dari rumah pukul lima pagi untuk berjoging.
Katanya, bagaimanapun, mangsa didapati tidak pulang ke rumah secara kebiasaannya pukul 8.30 pagi selepas melakukan aktiviti riadah tersebut.
"Cucu mangsa yang bimbang keadaan itu kemudiannya bertindak mencari neneknya dan menemui basikal kepunyaan mangsa berhampiran Sungai Langat.
"Berdasarkan siasatan awal, mangsa yang mengalami tekanan jiwa itu terjun ke dalam sungai susulan cucu wanita itu memberitahu neneknya pernah cuba membunuh diri minggu lalu," katanya dalam satu kenyataan di sini hari ini.
Jelas beliau, hasil bedah siasat mayat mangsa di Hospital Banting mendapati tiada sebarang kecederaan pada badan mangsa serta didapati mati akibat lemas.
Kes kini diklasifikasikan sebagai mati mengejut (SDR). - K! ONLINE

quote: We apologise for not being able to give away the Mercedes-Benz as planned and any disappointment this may cause.
content:
Donate to a charity and you could win a Mercedes-Benz car in a lucky draw - this was the promise made by The Given Company (TGC), a social enterprise launched in August.
With less than a month before the draw, TGC has informed donors that it had been cancelled and they would be getting a refund of their donations.
In a notice sent to donors on Oct 9, TGC founder Charles Tan blamed media reports and the controversy surrounding the lucky draw as reasons behind the cancellation.
He said: "While we expected and were prepared for detractors, having to address their concerns undoubtedly diverted our resources, delayed our marketing efforts and impacted overall sales."
The notice added that the draw, which had been scheduled for Nov 2, was cancelled so it could plan for the next draw next year.
Mr Tan added: "We apologise for not being able to give away the Mercedes-Benz as planned and any disappointment this may cause."
An edited version was also posted on the TGC website and its Facebook page.
TGC had touted its operating model of offering prizes to incentivise donors as a new way of helping charities raise money, which Mr Tan likened to the sale of charity raffle tickets.
The New Paper reported on Aug 31 that the Commissioner of Charities (COC) and Charity Council chairman Gerard Ee, among others, were critical of TGC's model as it did not promote the true spirit of donating.
Mr Ee told TNP on Tuesday he was glad the draw had been cancelled. He hoped TGC had done so in response to public opinion that incentivising donations undermines the value of charity and sends the wrong signal about giving.
The Office of the COC told TNP on Wednesday that it had met with TGC.
DONATING AMOUNT RAISED



​
"We understand that they have cancelled their inaugural lucky draw and will be offering a full refund to their supporters," the COC spokesman said.
"TGC also intends to honour the charitable intention by donating the amount raised to-date to the selected charities."
The spokesman said COC could not comment on TGC's intention to bring back the lucky draw as it does not have details of TGC's new operating model.
TGC said in August that as part of the lucky draw, 50,000 T-shirts would be sold for $20 each, with the proceeds going to the buyer's selected charity.
In the lucky draw, each buyer could win cash prizes ranging from $8 to $40, with the Mercedes-Benz as the grand prize.
Mr Tan said at the time: "It is about giving people a small little nudge to do something that they are not doing frequently enough."
He also said that TGC could offer a condominium unit as the grand prize in future draws, with TGC taking a 5 per cent to 10 per cent commission on each donation to cover costs.
A donor, Mr Jonathan Tan, a 29-year-old executive in a non-profit organisation, said he found out TGC had changed the grand prize from a Mercedes-Benz to a holiday when he checked its website on Monday.
Pointing out that TGC had not notified him of the change, he said: "I am not upset but disappointed. They are raising money for charities, so honouring the deal would have been good for their credibility."
According to the TGC notice to donors, TGC will be donating $13,000 to its partner charities.
The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, one of TGC's partner charities, told TNP: "The company has informed us of and provided an explanation for the cancellation.
"We understand their decision. We have been informed that full refunds will be provided and we will be following up to ensure this is done."
When TNP asked Mr Tan what TGC had done with the prizes that it claimed to have already bought, he declined to comment and directed TNP to its website and social media sites.
A check on the website shows a "dream car", an "amazing holiday" and a "luxury condominium" offered as prizes for draws in 2019.
Those who click on the "I'm interested" bar are asked to provide their personal details and how many tickets at $20 each they would like to buy.
This article was first published in The New Paper. Permission required for reproduction.

He said: "While we expected and were prepared for detractors, having to address their concerns undoubtedly diverted our resources, delayed our marketing efforts and impacted overall sales." The notice added that the draw, which had been scheduled for Nov 2, was cancelled so it could plan for the next draw next year. Mr Tan added: "We apologise for not being able to give away the Mercedes-Benz as planned and any disappointment this may cause." An edited version was also posted on the TGC website and its Facebook page. TGC had touted its operating model of offering prizes to incentivise donors as a new way of helping charities raise money, which Mr Tan likened to the sale of charity raffle tickets. The New Paper reported on Aug 31 that the Commissioner of Charities (COC) and Charity Council chairman Gerard Ee, among others, were critical of TGC's model as it did not promote the true spirit of donating. Mr Ee told TNP on Tuesday he was glad the draw had been cancelled. He hoped TGC had done so in response to public opinion that incentivising donations undermines the value of charity and sends the wrong signal about giving. The Office of the COC told TNP on Wednesday that it had met with TGC. DONATING AMOUNT RAISED ​ "We understand that they have cancelled their inaugural lucky draw and will be offering a full refund to their supporters," the COC spokesman said. "TGC also intends to honour the charitable intention by donating the amount raised to-date to the selected charities." The spokesman said COC could not comment on TGC's intention to bring back the lucky draw as it does not have details of TGC's new operating model. TGC said in August that as part of the lucky draw, 50,000 T-shirts would be sold for $20 each, with the proceeds going to the buyer's selected charity. In the lucky draw, each buyer could win cash prizes ranging from $8 to $40, with the Mercedes-Benz as the grand prize. Mr Tan said at the time: "It is about giving people a small little nudge to do something that they are not doing frequently enough." He also said that TGC could offer a condominium unit as the grand prize in future draws, with TGC taking a 5 per cent to 10 per cent commission on each donation to cover costs. A donor, Mr Jonathan Tan, a 29-year-old executive in a non-profit organisation, said he found out TGC had changed the grand prize from a Mercedes-Benz to a holiday when he checked its website on Monday. Pointing out that TGC had not notified him of the change, he said: "I am not upset but disappointed. They are raising money for charities, so honouring the deal would have been good for their credibility." According to the TGC notice to donors, TGC will be donating $13,000 to its partner charities. The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, one of TGC's partner charities, told TNP: "The company has informed us of and provided an explanation for the cancellation. "We understand their decision. We have been informed that full refunds will be provided and we will be following up to ensure this is done." When TNP asked Mr Tan what TGC had done with the prizes that it claimed to have already bought, he declined to comment and directed TNP to its website and social media sites. A check on the website shows a "dream car", an "amazing holiday" and a "luxury condominium" offered as prizes for draws in 2019. Those who click on the "I'm interested" bar are asked to provide their personal details and how many tickets at $20 each they would like to buy. This article was first published in The New Paper. Permission required for reproduction.

KOTA KINABALU: A human skeleton was discovered under a banana tree at Kampung Saga, Numbak in Menggatal Tuesday morning.
Kota Kinabalu police chief ACP Habibi Majinji said the skeleton was fully cloth when it was discovered by a villager.
“Initial police investigation believed the victim has been dead for three weeks.
“We are also trying to determine the gender and identity of the victim,” he said on Wednesday.
The skeleton has been taken to the Queen Elizabeth Hospital for further examination.
Habibi urged anyone with a missing relative to come forward and lodged a police report so appropriate investigation can be carry out.

quote: whereas the state prefers to repeat the grossly erroneous 2015 projections which property investors like to hear
content:
Nine workers died in the Bukit Kukus landslide which followed another landslide in Tanjung Bungah earlier. (Bernama pic)
PETALING JAYA: A spokesman for a coalition of 40 NGOs has rubbished Penang Chief Minister Chow Kon Yeow’s claims that Hong Kong would not have developed if it took heed of all the comments from civil society and stopped all development projects following disasters.
Chow said Hong Kong had a major landslide in the 1970s which killed nearly a hundred but was now technologically-advanced to build even on the steepest slopes after treating such disasters as valuable lessons.
Penang Forum steering committee member Khoo Salma Nasution took to Facebook today to issue a “brief reply” to Chow “since he doesn’t listen to NGOs”.
“Hong Kong may have learnt from its landslides, but Penang didn’t learn from Granito,” Khoo wrote, referring to the Granito project which made headlines last October following a fatal landslide at the construction site at Tanjung Bungah. Eleven lives were lost.
Penang Forum steering committee member Khoo Salma Nasution also urges state government to reveal how it will service RM1 billion federal loan.
“Hence, it allowed Bukit Kukus to happen under the watch of MBPP (Penang Island City Council),” she said.
Last month, nine workers died in a landslide at a road construction site on a hill slope in Bukit Kukus, Paya Terubong, on Penang island.
The official cause of the incident is yet to be known and is pending a state and police investigation. However, experts have claimed that proper hill-cutting procedures were not adhered to.
NGO: Many people live on mainland
Yesterday, Chow also touched on Penang’s projected population in the next 10 to 20 years in its Penang Transport Master Plan (PTMP), which the Penang Forum had said was unrealistic and high.
Chow had said the population projection by the project delivery partner of the PTMP was based on data from the Statistics Department.
He said official numbers show Penang had a population of 1.7 million last year and this is expected to grow by 25,000 to 30,000, or at a 1.5-2.5% rate each year in coming years.
“NGOs sometimes pluck figures from the sky, without referring to official statistics,” Chow said, adding that the government has to plan now to meet the needs of 2.2 to 2.4 million people in Penang by 2030.
Khoo said NGOs like Penang Forum had “plucked” the population statistics from the Statistics Department, “whereas the state prefers to repeat the grossly erroneous 2015 projections which property investors like to hear”.
“The island cannot hold two plus million people. Many Penangites actually live in Seberang Perai (on the mainland).
“The state wants to take a RM1 billion federal loan to carry out RM16.4 billion worth of projects. So, please reveal your financing and project completion schedules to assure us the state won’t go bankrupt in the meantime.
“After STP2 (Seri Tanjung Pinang Phase II) island reclamation and selling Jerejak, the state can’t wait to sell its three islands being reclaimed to interested parties… need I say more?”
The STP2 is a 304ha reclamation project approved “in principle” by the Penang government in April 2011.
The Penang Forum had previously raised concerns over an environmental impact assessment (EIA) report of the STP 2, including on sedimentation, erosion and how it affected the coast’s wildlife.
Despite a series of engagements, the STP 2 project was approved by the Department of Environment in April 2014. The reclamation project is expected to be completed by the end of the year.
Meanwhile, on Jerajak Island, which was once used to house the country’s main leprosy sanatorium, Chow had previously said a developer was looking to turn the southern portion of the island into a theme park, as part of a larger master plan.
This plan was submitted to the state government by landowners Tropical Island Resort Sdn Bhd in August 2016.
The master plan, which includes a bridge from the Bayan Mutiara area, was approved although Chow said local authorities had yet to receive a request for planning permission for the theme park.
He said an EIA of the entire project was submitted to the DoE on June 21 and was approved on July 20.

quote: incredible violence towards the police
content:
Demonstrators faced riot police on the Champs Elysees at the end of a protest by the French “yellow vests” (gilets jaunes) movement in central Paris on December 22. (AFP pic)
PARIS: French President Emmanuel Macron called for “order” on Sunday after a sixth weekend of “yellow vest” anti-government protests marked by dwindling participation and a violent attack on police in Paris.
Speaking during a visit to the central African state of Chad where he was visiting French troops serving in a counter-terrorism force Macron said: “There must be order now, calm and harmony. Our country needs it.”
“It needs harmony, unity, sincere commitment to strong collective causes and we must heal the divisions,” said the 41-year-old centrist, who has struggled to tamp down the anger of the working poor in smalltown and rural France over falling spending power and policies seen as tilted towards the rich.
A total of 38,600 people took part in a sixth round of nationwide protests on Saturday, according to the interior ministry — around half the number that demonstrated a week earlier.
In Paris, the scene of fierce clashes and widespread destruction in previous weeks, the protests were mainly peaceful.
But as evening fell, violence broke out again on the iconic Champs-Elysees avenue.
In one incident that caused widespread outrage, a group of three police officers on motorbike were forced to make a hasty escape after coming under attack near the Champs-Elysees from a group of demonstrators, who threw electric scooters, paving stones and other objects at them.
A video of the incident, which was widely shared on social media, showed one officer pulling his gun and pointing it at the advancing protesters.
He and his two colleagues — one of whom had his motorbike knocked to the ground — then made their getaway.
The video showed that, seconds before the attack, the police had lobbed stun grenades at a group of protesters, who were some distance away.
Speaking to BFMTV channel Macron said those responsible for the violence would face “the most severe” legal punishment.
Prime Minister Edouard Philippe for his part denounced the “incredible violence towards the police”.
He also took aim at protesters who sang a song by controversial comedian Dieudonne M’Bala M’Bala, a convicted anti-Semite, outside Sacre-Coeur church in Paris as well as those who decapitated an effigy of Macron in the western Charente region — two other incidents seen as evidence of growing radicalisation and the presence of extremists within the movement.
“There can be no trivialising of such gestures which must draw unanimous condemnation and be punished by the law,” Philippe tweeted.
The number of demonstrators has been trending downwards since 282,000 people turned out for the first Saturday protest against planned fuel tax hikes on November 17.
From there the protests quickly morphed into a full-scale revolt against Macron’s policies, aloof, top-down governing style, and the political class as a whole.
Leader faces charges 
Saturday’s numbers represented a sharp drop from last week, however, when Macron announced an income increase for minimum-wage earners and rolled back tax increases on pensioners, among other measures.
Around 2,000 protesters gathered in Paris, compared to 4,000 last week, police said.
A total of 142 people were detained and 19 taken into police custody in the capital, including one of leaders of the movement, Eric Drouet.
Drouet, a truck driver, was to be brought before an investigating magistrate Sunday to be charged with carrying an illegal weapon in the form of a block of wood and “participating in a group formed to commit violence or destruction”. He denies the charges.
The protests have dealt a blow to the French economy, particularly the retail trade.
Junior economy minister Agnes Pannier-Runacher said French stores reported an average drop-off of 25% in sales compared with the same period a year earlier.
Ten people have died in incidents linked to the demonstrations, mostly in accidents at roadblocks set up by the protesters.

quote: Anda perlukan kerajaan persekutuan untuk meneliti masalah anda. Jadi saya akan memanfaatkan kelebihan ini untuk kempen.
content: PRK CAMERON HIGHLANDS | Calon Pakatan Harapan (PH) M Manogaran percaya bahawa sekiranya BN meletakkan calon Orang Asli pada pilihan raya kecil (PRK) Cameron Highlands, strategi itu tidak akan berhasil.Bagi menjelaskan hujahnya, ahli DAP itu memberikan perumpamaan berkaitan kuih."Ikut perkiraan BN, mereka fikir... Mereka tak faham. Orang Melayu tak beli kuih dari gerai Orang Asli. Saya tak fikir mereka (orang Melayu) akan undi Orang Asli."Orang Melayu akan tanya: kenapa tak ada calon orang Melayu? Kenapa letak Orang Asli?' Orang Cina, India juga tidak akan undi Orang Asli," katanya kepada Malaysiakini.Manogaran berkata demikian sebagai mengulas spekulasi kemungkinan BN mencalonkan bekas bekas pegawai polis Orang Asli Ramli Mohd Noor pada PRK 26 Jan ini.Manogaran berkata Ramli juga tidak dapat meraih majoriti undi Orang Asli. Masyarakat Orang Asli mewakili 20 peratus daripada keseluruhan pengundi di Cameron Highlands. Sementara orang Melayu mewakili 34 peratus.Bukan cara pilih calon"Dengan (pengundi) Orang Asli, mereka (BN) akan kata 'Dia orang kamu sendiri. Apa kata undi dia?'"Kami perlu balas dengan kata, 'Dia Orang Asli tapidia belum pernah diuji, dia belum pernah terdedah kepada apa-apa.. Kalau dia menang pun, dia tidak akan dalam kerajaan, jadi siapa yang dapat berkhidmat apa lagi Orang Asli kini memerlukan infrastruktur asas?'"Siapa akan beri mereka kemudahan yang mereka sangat perlukan kerana mereka sudah diabaikan begitu lama?" katanya.Untuk menegaskan lagi hujahnya, Manogaran memetik bekas presiden MIC S Samy Vellu sebagai contoh."Sammy Vellu memimpin orang India selama 30 tahun. Apa yang dia beri kepada orang India? Jadi jangan guna logik itu, sokong orang yang dapat selesaikan masalah. Kempen saya akan menggunakan Samy Vellu sebagai contoh."Berapa banyak orang Cina rugi di bawah MCA? Jadi itu bukan cara memilih calon menjadi wakil rakyat," katanya.Manogaran berkata, tidak seperti orang Cina dan golongan kelas menengah India, Orang Asli masih memerlukan bantuan daripada kerajaan persekutuan."Anda perlukan kerajaan persekutuan untuk meneliti masalah anda. Jadi saya akan memanfaatkan kelebihan ini untuk kempen."Saya tak fikir dia (Ramli) akan dapat undi Orang Asli sepenuhnya. Mereka akan lihat pada Jakoa," katanya.Penamaan calon bagi PRK Cameron Highlands akan diadakan 12 Jan ini. Sementara BN dijangka mengumumkan calon mereka pagi esok.[Baca berita asal]

quote: We have over 60 tribes in South Sudan with different beliefs.
content:
Juba, South Sudan - On the side of a road a man stands by a wall ready to fight. He picks up a piece of broken glass to defend himself.Â 
The white cloth around him falls off and he is now bare-chested, facing five policemen. They are wearing medical gloves.Â 
"I don't want to go. Leave me alone," the man yells.
Dr Atong Ayuel, one of only three practising South Sudanese psychiatrists in the country, watches the scene unfold.
Since 2015, she has led a project supporting mentally ill homeless people, providing baths, fresh clothes, a medical check and long lasting anti-psychotics if necessary.
"It's okay. Leave him alone. We don't force anyone to come," Dr Atong* tells the police and then boards a bus.
As part of the initiative, Atong, with a group of psychologists and policemen, hop onto a Juba's Teaching Hospital bus three days a month and look out for people to help.








Dr Atong Ayuel makes sure a homeless man who refuses to partake in her project is left alone, since participation is voluntary [Jasmin Bauomy/Al Jazeera]





They treat 20 to 30 homeless patients with mental conditions a month. Over time, many have become willing participants, with some returning to families and jobs, but that's not always the case.Â 
After being treated at hospital, they are usually returned to where they were picked up.
"We don't have the infrastructure to keep them," Atong says. There are only 12 beds and two nurses in the mental health ward at the hospital she works at.
Aside from overseeing the GEMS (Goats, Education, Medicine and Sustainability) - funded project, Atong, 40, treats hospital patients and people around the country, and heads the government's mental health department.
The two other practicing psychiatrists are Dr George Nazario and Dr Richard Wani.
George treats patients at Juba's main prison and the outpatient clinic. Richard works at the hospital and University of Juba.








After reaching the hospital, the homeless get a haircut, a shave, the opportunity for a bath, fresh clothes, a medical check and long-lasting anti-psychotics if needed [Jasmin Bauomy/Al Jazeera]





As the director of the mental health department, Atong develops policies for the country's 12.5 million people, many of whom are trying to recover from the trauma caused by decades of conflict and displacement.
South Sudan suffered two civil wars before it won independence from Sudan in 2011, and is only now regaining its footing from its own civil war that lasted from 2013 until 2018. The country's three practicing psychiatrists and 29 psychologists are all in Juba.
After independence, the South Sudanese government had to create a healthcare system from scratch. Thirteen years later, Atong and her colleagues are still struggling to provide mental healthcare.Â 
The Juba Teaching Hospital is the only public medical facility that provides psychiatric care; the availability of psychotropic drugs is inconsistent and limited.Â 
If the 12-bed ward is full, or if a patient is not eligible to take a bed, the mentally ill are often detained in Juba's Central Prison.








One of the psychologists sits in the bus with the homeless to conduct preliminary medical interviews and assesses their mental health [Jasmin Bauomy/Al Jazeera]





Others are transferred to prison from medical facilities or taken to the detention centre directly by family members.Â 
In May 2016, according to rights group Amnesty, the prison held 66 male and 16 female mentally ill patients.Â 
While those numbers have dipped, Atong expects them to rise once again given the lack of resources.
Outside of Juba, psychiatrist Jairam Ramakrishnan, a New Zealand doctor who works for Doctors Without Borders (MSF), has been based at a clinic at a Protection of Civilians (PoC) site in Malakal, in Upper Nile State, a highly contested area, for more than a year.
"On a monthly basis we get anywhere between 30 to 40 new patients," he tells Al Jazeera.Â 
Including follow-up consultations and first visits, there are about 250 mental health cases a month.Â 
The site is home to about 25,000 displaced people. When the United Nations force in South Sudan (UNMISS) established the camp after an outbreak of violence in 2014, improving living conditions wasn't a priority.








Psychologists and policemen drive through Juba three times a month to pick up and care for mentally ill homeless people [Jasmin Bauomy/Al Jazeera]





To recover, Ramakrishnan says, patients need "basics like food, housing, safety, security, education transfer and employment. [...] So, even though a person may have a good chance of recovery from an acute severe mental illness", it is difficult to provide a setting where this is possible.Â 
"Social aspects play a big role for mental illness and social support systems are very weak in a protracted conflict."Â 
As well as battling for more resources, the few psychiatrists in charge also have to tackle misconceptions.
"Mental illness is a huge problem in South Sudan," Atong says.Â "We have over 60 tribes in South Sudan with different beliefs."Â 
Most communities believe in supernatural possession or punishment by higher powers, as opposed to accepting a mental illness diagnosis, Atong says.








A policeman is on the lookout for possible new patients. He is one of a handful of security forces that help Dr Atong find patients on the streets of Juba [Jasmin Bauomy/Al Jazeera]





Paradise Agaak Henry, one of Atong's patients in Juba, has been diagnosed with schizophrenia.Â 
She is in her 20s, loves fashion and beauty products, and is a keen student enrolled in paediatrics at the University of Upper Nile.Â 
"What makes me sad is to see what my former schoolmates are doing now. Some of them have finished their universities and I'm still in my first year," she says, mourning the time she spent taking care of her mental health. "The devil attacked me and I tried to die. I didn't eat or drink for four days."
Her neighbours took her to church where believers tried to rid her of what they thought was an evil spirit.Â 
"They just prayed and cried. They beat me."Â 
Her family later brought her to hospital, where she spent two months in Atong's ward.
"It's a stigma to be diagnosed as mentally ill," Atong says, "people believe that it runs in the family. So when a family member is diagnosed, it could be harder for other family members to get married for example."Â 
People would rather be known to be possessed than have a treatable mental illness, she explains.Â 
Paradise is improving. Asked whether faith or the psychiatrist helped, she says: "First of all Jesus, and then Dr Atong."
This is my country. It's the country I have. We've had a bad start, but we're committed to create a better South Sudan for all.
Atong Ayuel, psychiatrist

Stigma is not limited to patients.
Medical professionals who choose psychiatry are looked down on by their peers, Atong explains, and their salaries often don't match their colleagues.
Atong had earlier chosen paediatrics, but changed track when she encountered a mentally ill patient, who ended up being sent to prison.Â 
Her colleagues were shocked to see her "waste her talent" after she graduated second-best in her year from the University of Bahr Al Ghazal College.Â 
There is also a lack of accessible training, but over the last two years Atong has managed to include psychiatry as part of the curriculum at the universities of Bahr el Ghazal, Juba and Upper Nile.Â 
In 2017, to help doctors at least identify mental illnesses, the World Health Organization (WHO) committed to supporting the country's health ministry in training supervisors and healthcare workers across the country.
"However, due to limited financial resources to support procurement of medication, supervision of health workers and procurement of other materials, largely not much could be done until the fourth quarter of 2018," Dr Joseph Mogga of the WHO told Al Jazeera, adding the organisation would offer further support this year.
Atong welcomes WHO's support. She knows the lack of funds makes it hard to move the needle.Â 
The country's 2017-18Â budget allocated two percent to the health sector - or about $2.7m. None of that is currently allocated for mental health.
Atong is well aware of underinvestment in healthcare but small victories keep her going.Â 
"Since the current minister of health [Dr Riek Gai Kok] came into power, he put mental health as a priority," she says. He established the department of mental health within his ministry.Â 
In 2014 South Sudan commemorated mental health day for the first time.Â 
"Even in Western countries, mental healthcare always lacks [lags] behind a little compared to general healthcare."Â 
In a country where general healthcare isn't easy to come by, "you can imagine how difficult it is to establish a mental healthcare system", says Jairam of MSF.Â 
But there are promising plans for 2019.Â 
India's Central Public Works Department (CPWD) has taken on the challenge of building a new psychiatric hospital in Juba, next to the current psychiatric ward.
Atong plans to create a mental health policy within the national general health policy.Â 
"This is my country. It's the country I have... We've had a bad start, but we're committed to create a better South Sudan for all," she says before rushing off to see another patient.Â 
Doctors* are usually referred to by their first name in South Sudan
This report was made possible through a reporting fellowship from the International Women's Media Foundation (IWMF) and local journalist Samir Bol

Juba, South Sudan - On the side of a road a man stands by a wall ready to fight. He picks up a piece of broken glass to defend himself.Â 
The white cloth around him falls off and he is now bare-chested, facing five policemen. They are wearing medical gloves.Â 
"I don't want to go. Leave me alone," the man yells.
Dr Atong Ayuel, one of only three practising South Sudanese psychiatrists in the country, watches the scene unfold.
Since 2015, she has led a project supporting mentally ill homeless people, providing baths, fresh clothes, a medical check and long lasting anti-psychotics if necessary.
"It's okay. Leave him alone. We don't force anyone to come," Dr Atong* tells the police and then boards a bus.
As part of the initiative, Atong, with a group of psychologists and policemen, hop onto a Juba's Teaching Hospital bus three days a month and look out for people to help.








Dr Atong Ayuel makes sure a homeless man who refuses to partake in her project is left alone, since participation is voluntary [Jasmin Bauomy/Al Jazeera]





They treat 20 to 30 homeless patients with mental conditions a month. Over time, many have become willing participants, with some returning to families and jobs, but that's not always the case.Â 
After being treated at hospital, they are usually returned to where they were picked up.
"We don't have the infrastructure to keep them," Atong says. There are only 12 beds and two nurses in the mental health ward at the hospital she works at.
Aside from overseeing the GEMS (Goats, Education, Medicine and Sustainability) - funded project, Atong, 40, treats hospital patients and people around the country, and heads the government's mental health department.
The two other practicing psychiatrists are Dr George Nazario and Dr Richard Wani.
George treats patients at Juba's main prison and the outpatient clinic. Richard works at the hospital and University of Juba.








After reaching the hospital, the homeless get a haircut, a shave, the opportunity for a bath, fresh clothes, a medical check and long-lasting anti-psychotics if needed [Jasmin Bauomy/Al Jazeera]





As the director of the mental health department, Atong develops policies for the country's 12.5 million people, many of whom are trying to recover from the trauma caused by decades of conflict and displacement.
South Sudan suffered two civil wars before it won independence from Sudan in 2011, and is only now regaining its footing from its own civil war that lasted from 2013 until 2018. The country's three practicing psychiatrists and 29 psychologists are all in Juba.
After independence, the South Sudanese government had to create a healthcare system from scratch. Thirteen years later, Atong and her colleagues are still struggling to provide mental healthcare.Â 
The Juba Teaching Hospital is the only public medical facility that provides psychiatric care; the availability of psychotropic drugs is inconsistent and limited.Â 
If the 12-bed ward is full, or if a patient is not eligible to take a bed, the mentally ill are often detained in Juba's Central Prison.








One of the psychologists sits in the bus with the homeless to conduct preliminary medical interviews and assesses their mental health [Jasmin Bauomy/Al Jazeera]





Others are transferred to prison from medical facilities or taken to the detention centre directly by family members.Â 
In May 2016, according to rights group Amnesty, the prison held 66 male and 16 female mentally ill patients.Â 
While those numbers have dipped, Atong expects them to rise once again given the lack of resources.
Outside of Juba, psychiatrist Jairam Ramakrishnan, a New Zealand doctor who works for Doctors Without Borders (MSF), has been based at a clinic at a Protection of Civilians (PoC) site in Malakal, in Upper Nile State, a highly contested area, for more than a year.
"On a monthly basis we get anywhere between 30 to 40 new patients," he tells Al Jazeera.Â 
Including follow-up consultations and first visits, there are about 250 mental health cases a month.Â 
The site is home to about 25,000 displaced people. When the United Nations force in South Sudan (UNMISS) established the camp after an outbreak of violence in 2014, improving living conditions wasn't a priority.








Psychologists and policemen drive through Juba three times a month to pick up and care for mentally ill homeless people [Jasmin Bauomy/Al Jazeera]





To recover, Ramakrishnan says, patients need "basics like food, housing, safety, security, education transfer and employment. [...] So, even though a person may have a good chance of recovery from an acute severe mental illness", it is difficult to provide a setting where this is possible.Â 
"Social aspects play a big role for mental illness and social support systems are very weak in a protracted conflict."Â 
As well as battling for more resources, the few psychiatrists in charge also have to tackle misconceptions.
"Mental illness is a huge problem in South Sudan," Atong says.Â "We have over 60 tribes in South Sudan with different beliefs."Â 
Most communities believe in supernatural possession or punishment by higher powers, as opposed to accepting a mental illness diagnosis, Atong says.








A policeman is on the lookout for possible new patients. He is one of a handful of security forces that help Dr Atong find patients on the streets of Juba [Jasmin Bauomy/Al Jazeera]





Paradise Agaak Henry, one of Atong's patients in Juba, has been diagnosed with schizophrenia.Â 
She is in her 20s, loves fashion and beauty products, and is a keen student enrolled in paediatrics at the University of Upper Nile.Â 
"What makes me sad is to see what my former schoolmates are doing now. Some of them have finished their universities and I'm still in my first year," she says, mourning the time she spent taking care of her mental health. "The devil attacked me and I tried to die. I didn't eat or drink for four days."
Her neighbours took her to church where believers tried to rid her of what they thought was an evil spirit.Â 
"They just prayed and cried. They beat me."Â 
Her family later brought her to hospital, where she spent two months in Atong's ward.
"It's a stigma to be diagnosed as mentally ill," Atong says, "people believe that it runs in the family. So when a family member is diagnosed, it could be harder for other family members to get married for example."Â 
People would rather be known to be possessed than have a treatable mental illness, she explains.Â 
Paradise is improving. Asked whether faith or the psychiatrist helped, she says: "First of all Jesus, and then Dr Atong."
This is my country. It's the country I have. We've had a bad start, but we're committed to create a better South Sudan for all.
Atong Ayuel, psychiatrist

Stigma is not limited to patients.
Medical professionals who choose psychiatry are looked down on by their peers, Atong explains, and their salaries often don't match their colleagues.
Atong had earlier chosen paediatrics, but changed track when she encountered a mentally ill patient, who ended up being sent to prison.Â 
Her colleagues were shocked to see her "waste her talent" after she graduated second-best in her year from the University of Bahr Al Ghazal College.Â 
There is also a lack of accessible training, but over the last two years Atong has managed to include psychiatry as part of the curriculum at the universities of Bahr el Ghazal, Juba and Upper Nile.Â 
In 2017, to help doctors at least identify mental illnesses, the World Health Organization (WHO) committed to supporting the country's health ministry in training supervisors and healthcare workers across the country.
"However, due to limited financial resources to support procurement of medication, supervision of health workers and procurement of other materials, largely not much could be done until the fourth quarter of 2018," Dr Joseph Mogga of the WHO told Al Jazeera, adding the organisation would offer further support this year.
Atong welcomes WHO's support. She knows the lack of funds makes it hard to move the needle.Â 
The country's 2017-18Â budget allocated two percent to the health sector - or about $2.7m. None of that is currently allocated for mental health.
Atong is well aware of underinvestment in healthcare but small victories keep her going.Â 
"Since the current minister of health [Dr Riek Gai Kok] came into power, he put mental health as a priority," she says. He established the department of mental health within his ministry.Â 
In 2014 South Sudan commemorated mental health day for the first time.Â 
"Even in Western countries, mental healthcare always lacks [lags] behind a little compared to general healthcare."Â 
In a country where general healthcare isn't easy to come by, "you can imagine how difficult it is to establish a mental healthcare system", says Jairam of MSF.Â 
But there are promising plans for 2019.Â 
India's Central Public Works Department (CPWD) has taken on the challenge of building a new psychiatric hospital in Juba, next to the current psychiatric ward.
Atong plans to create a mental health policy within the national general health policy.Â 
"This is my country. It's the country I have... We've had a bad start, but we're committed to create a better South Sudan for all," she says before rushing off to see another patient.Â 
Doctors* are usually referred to by their first name in South Sudan

quote: Saya tidak begitu pasti sama ada kita perlu segera memperkukuhkan Ringgit kerana ia akan membayangkan bahawa kita akan terus bergantung kuat pada import.
content:
Oh Ei Sun/FMT
Seorang penganalisis berkata, kenyataan menteri yang tidak tetap dan saling bercanggah mengenai isu berkaitan projek utama memberi kesan ke atas keyakinan pelabur, sekali gus mencadangkan supaya Putrajaya mewujudkan sistem jurucakap kerajaan.
Bercakap kepada FMT, felo kanan Institut Hal ehwal Antarabangsa Singapura, Oh Ei Sun berkata, jurucakap itu hendaklah merupakan seorang diplomat profesional atau sekurang-kurangnya seorang yang mahir dalam bidang terbabit, bukannya pihak kementerian secara berasingan.
Terbaru, Menteri Kewangan Lim Guan Eng dan Menteri Hal-ehwal Ekonomi, Datuk Seri Mohamed Azmin Ali dikritik keras oleh pembangkang berikutan kenyataan mereka yang saling bercanggah berhubung status projek Laluan Keretapi Pantai Timur (ECRL).
Oh juga berkata, sehingga kini kerajaan pimpinan Pakatan Harapan (PH) belum mengetengahkan rancangan yang tersusun dan konsisten untuk memulihkan keadaan ekonomi yang merosot.
Berhubung kejatuhan besar nilai Ringgit berbanding Baht Thailand serta pencapaian ekonomi negara Thai walaupun berada di bawah pemerintahan tentera, Oh berkata, perbandingan mata wang antara 2 ekonomi yang serupa tidaklah terlalu bermakna kerana akan berlaku “turun-naik yang kerap” antara kedua-duanya.

“Semalam Ringgit mencecah rekod terendah berbanding Baht pada kadar tukaran RM13.15 bagi 100 Baht (RM1 bersamaan 7.60 Baht).
“Saya tidak begitu pasti sama ada kita perlu segera memperkukuhkan Ringgit kerana ia akan membayangkan bahawa kita akan terus bergantung kuat pada import.
“Sebaliknya kita harus mengambil kesempatan ke atas nilai Ringgit yang relatif lebih lemah itu dengan memperkukuhkan eksport dan memperkuat faktor bukan benda kita seperti kerajaan yang bersih dan cekap.”
Bagi mencapai tujuan itu kata Oh, “mesej selamat datang” Malaysia kepada pelabur dan komuniti perniagaan haruslah positif dan konsisten.
Berkaitan Thailand, Oh berkata, negara itu mengekalkan pemisahan jelas antara tindak-tanduk politik dengan dasar ekonomi.
“Sama ada ia merupakan kerajaan awam atau tentera, dasar pro-perniagaan dan pro-pelaburan tetap diteruskan.
“Malah dalam keadaan krisis yang paling buruk pun, rakyat Thai tidak akan merosakkan kemampuan produktiviti ekonomi mereka.”
Beliau berkata, kerajaan Malaysia boleh belajar daripada keadaan itu dengan memisahkan politik daripada pengurusan sebenar kerajaan.

content:
NEW YORK: Boeing reported a strong fourth quarter on Wednesday (Jan 30) and offered a bullish 2019 outlook that implies the company will not see a significant hit from US-China trade tensions.The US aerospace giant, which has been boosted by a multi-year plane building boom amid surging global air travel demand, reported fourth-quarter profits of US$3.4 billion, up 3.1 per cent from the same period a year ago.
Revenues were US$28.3 billion, up 14.4 per cent.Several of the company's financial figures were company records, including annual revenues topping US$100 billion for the first time at US$101.1 billion."Across the enterprise, our team delivered strong core operating performance and customer focus, driving record revenues, earnings and cash flow and further extending our global aerospace industry leadership in 2018," said Boeing Chief Executive Dennis Muilenburg.Boeing has been ramping up production of its single-aisle 737 plane, which accounted for more than half of the company's commercial deliveries in 2018.
On a conference call in October following its previous earnings report, Boeing executives said production of the 737 had reached 52 planes per month, up from the prior 47 and a key step on a planned ramp-up to 57 in 2019.In October, Muilenburg said he remained committed to China as "one of the fastest growing commercial aviation markets in the world" and was taking a long-term view that "there's strong reasons in both the US and China to have a healthy, prosperous aerospace industry."Boeing is scheduled to hold its fourth-quarter conference call later on Wednesday morning.In December, Boeing opened a new "completion and delivery centre" in Zhoushan, China where 737 planes are flown into the country from Seattle and interior work is completed.
China is expected to account for about 18 per cent of the new planes built over the next 20 years, according to Boeing figures.Some major companies, such as Apple, FedEx and Caterpillar, have in recent weeks cited sluggishness in China as a headwind for their results.But other companies, including General Motors and Nike, have described solid demand despite slowing growth in China in the wake of a protracted US-China trade war.Another round of talks between the two governments started in Washington on Wednesday, with the Chinese team led by Vice Premier Liu He and the American side by US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer.Boeing projected 2019 profits of US$19.90 to US$20.10 per share, well above the US$18.31 seen by analysts.It expects to deliver between 895 and 905 commercial planes, up from 806 in 2018. Boeing's most popular aircraft have moved past the initial production phases when costs are higher into a stage of increased plane delivery that is more profitable.Shares jumped 5.1 per cent to US$383.49 in early trading.

quote: Mereka adalah antara dalang dalam penerbitan bon 1MDB berjumlah USD6.5 bilion atau RM26 bilion yang bersubahat dengan penyangak di Malaysia untuk menyelewengkan wang rakyat Malaysia.
content:
KUALA LUMPUR –  Menteri Kewangan, Lim Guan Eng mengakhiri ucapan pembentangan Belanjawan 2019 di Dewan Rakyat hari ini dengan meminta penyangak yang telah mencuri wang rakyat supaya memulangkan wang tersebut kepada negara dan bersedia dihadapkan ke muka pengadilan.
Bagi mereka yang masih menyokong penyangak itu pula, katanya, pohonlah maaf dan letak jawatan daripada penjawat awam.
Dalam ucapan belanjawan julung kali oleh kerajaan Pakatan Harapan selepas memenangi Pilihan Raya Umum ke-14 (PRU14) pada 9 Mei lalu, Guan Eng merumuskan bahawa keputusan rakyat untuk memilih kerajaan sekarang adalah betul.
Ini terbukti apabila semalam di Amerika Syarikat, dua bekas pegawai Goldman Sachs Group Inc, Tim Leissner dan Roger Ng telah ditangkap dan didakwa oleh Jabatan Kehakiman Amerika Syarikat.
“Mereka adalah antara dalang dalam penerbitan bon 1MDB berjumlah USD6.5 bilion atau RM26 bilion yang bersubahat dengan penyangak di Malaysia untuk menyelewengkan wang rakyat Malaysia.
“Berita yang lebih baik ialah Jho Low, watak utama dalam skandal ini telahpun didakwa (indicted in absentia) di Amerika Syarikat,” katanya.
Beliau berkata, sungguhpun terdapat perbezaan, rakyat Malaysia adalah istimewa kerana tanpa mengira kaum, agama ataupun latar belakang, kita masih bersedia untuk bekerja sama dan saling mempercayai satu sama lain.
Katanya, Malaysia sudah bersih dan kita berbangga bahawa kini Malaysia bersih semula.
“Kepada mereka yang tersesat di hujung, baliklah ke pangkal jalan. Amar makruf nahi mungkar. Marilah kita menuju ke hadapan dengan penuh harapan. Malaysia Wibawa, Ekonomi Dinamik, Rakyat Sejahtera,” katanya. – MalaysiaGazette

quote: Saya selaku family Aniq agak terkilan dengan posting ini. Saya rasa ini bukan bahan lawak jenaka untuk dipertontonkan. Lagi-lagi muka terpampang dalam ni.
content:
Dapatkan berita yang paling viral setiap hari:






Sebagai seorang guru pastinya ingin berkongsi kisah-kisah yang terjadi dekat dalam kelas. Maklumlah, murid-murid ni ada macam-macam perangai. Tapi walau apa pun, gambar anak murid tidak patutlah dimuat naik lagi-lagi kalau ianya mengenai sesuatu yang memalukan.
Baru-baru ni, seorang guru telah berkongsi di Facebook mengenai dua orang pelajarnya dan nampaknya keluarga salah seorang pelajar terbabit terguris hati dengan entri tersebut. Katanya,
“Saya selaku family Aniq agak terkilan dengan posting ini. Saya rasa ini bukan bahan lawak jenaka untuk dipertontonkan. Lagi-lagi muka terpampang dalam ni.”
Sumber: Facebook
Bukan itu sahaja, kata individu itu, pelajar tu sendiri bernama Aniq turut rasa malu sehinggakan dia menangis kerana orang ramai menggelakkannya sehingga dipinggirkan. Apa sebenarnya yang guru itu dah lakukan?
Sebelum itu, guru tersebut telah menceritakan tentang dua orang pelajarnya yang bergaduh. Biasalah budak-budak. Namun, dalam pergaduhan tersebut, telah berlaku ejek mengejek di mana pelajar perempuan itu digelar “burger”, manakala pelajar perempuan itu mengejek Aniq sebagai “burger hangus”. Kata guru itu,
“Adoiii, saya terus tergelak besar sebab tak tahan dengan ejekan mereka berdua.
“Sabar jelah kan, Bebudak ni kaitkan saiz badan dengan burger. Saya pun suruh mereka bermaafan sesama mereka. Serius kalau saya tengok gambar ni memang akan ketawa sendiri.”
Gambar hiasan
Hal ini menyebabkan ahli keluarga Aniq terasa hati kerana merasakan tidak wajar untuk guru itu memuat naik posting tersebut sehingga mengundang banyak komen yang rata-rata menjadikan Aniq sebagai bahan gelak.
“Yang gelak tu semua adalah ibu bapa. Kalau kena pada anak sendiri confirm korang akan naik angin. Budak tu orang tak gelak sangat sebab kulit cerah.”
Bukan itu je, katanya entri tersebut juga dah mengguris perasaan ibu Aniq kerana seolah-olah dah menghina fizikal anaknya.
“Bagi cikgu ini mungkin hal budak-budak, tapi tidak pada ibu Aniq.”
Gambar hiasan
Selain itu, dia juga mengatakan sekiranya benar Aniq telah melakukan kesalahan, guru itu sepatutnya bersemuka dengan ibu bapa dan bukannya dengan cara memuat naik kisah di media sosial.
Kita kenalah berhati-hati hal macam ni. Mungkin guru itu pun tak menyangka akan jadi sampai macam ni. Biarlah ini menjadi pengajaran untuk semua.

quote: Some wives agree to allow their husbands to be polygamous but do not like to appear in court.
content:
The Perak government plans to amend Section 23 of the Islamic Family Enactment (Perak) 2004 to make polygamy easier for Muslim men.
Perak exco Asmuni Awi said under the existing enactment, the Syariah Court’s hands were tied so long as the first wife does not appear in court to state her case.
“Some wives agree to allow their husbands to be polygamous but do not like to appear in court.
"So the amendments will give the court the discretion whether to call the wife to appear in court,” he said.
Asmuni said this after launching the Perak Islamic Religious Council’s matchmaking website Cinta Sakinah and 'Understanding Polygamy in Perak' module in Ipoh today.
The website was made accessible today.
- Bernama

"Some wives agree to allow their husbands to be polygamous but do not like to appear in court. "So the amendments will give the court the discretion whether to call the wife to appear in court," he said. Asmuni said this after launching the Perak Islamic Religious Council's matchmaking website Cinta Sakinah and 'Understanding Polygamy in Perak' module in Ipoh today. The website was made accessible today. - Bernama

quote: It consolidated the gains from last month and strong growth in full-time roles points to a thriving jobs market.
content:
By BLOOMBERG
SYDNEY • Australian employment surged in October as the central bank’s record-low interest-rates spurred hiring, while the jobless rate remained at a six-year low despite an expanding workforce.
Jobs rose 32,800 from September, led by full-time hiring. Unemployment rate held at 5% as participation rose to 65.6%.
The report suggests the Reserve Bank of Australia’s (RBA) patience — after keeping the cash rate at 1.5% for more than two years — is now being rewarded with stronger employment and faster economic growth. Governor Philip Lowe is betting on a tightening labour market to fuel wage growth and inflation and lay the ground for the first rate increase since 2010.
“The RBA would be very happy with today’s report,” said Callam Pickering, economist at global jobs website Indeed, who previously worked at the RBA. “It consolidated the gains from last month and strong growth in full-time roles points to a thriving jobs market.”
The Australian dollar rose to 72.70 US cents (RM3.05) at 2:34pm in Sydney yesterday from 72.35 cents before the report. Traders are now pricing in about a 40% chance of a rate hike in August next year, from 25% before the data.
Improved hiring momentum and faster wage growth “is building the case for the RBA to start normalising monetary policy next year. “If current trends persist, we’d expect a 25-basis-point increase in the cash rate target to 1.75% by the fourth quarter (4Q) of 2019,” said Tamara Mast Henderson of Bloomberg Economics.
The data followed a report on Wednesday showing wages rose 2.3% in the 3Q, the fastest annual pace in three years. Still, economists noted the outcome was boosted by a hike in the minimum wage. Inflation, meanwhile, is still just below the bottom of the central bank’s 2% to 3% target.
“Much progress still needs to be made, which suggests that a rate hike in the near term is unlikely, but it is still a step in the right direction,” Pickering said. “Wage growth, rather than employment, is the more pressing issue for the RBA.”
Results by state: New South Wales led gains by state, adding 16,300 jobs, while the biggest loss of 3,500 roles was seen in Victoria. Queensland’s unemployment rate jumped to 6.3%, the nation’s highest, while New South Wales remained at 4.4%.

quote: Anugerah ini mengiktiraf dan menghargai semua pihak dalam banyak pasukan yang terlibat dalam PETRONAS secara menyeluruh.
content:
Petroliam Nasional Bhd (PETRONAS) memenangi tiga anugerah pada majlis Anugerah Tenaga Asia Pasifik bagi Majlis Tenaga, pada Rabu.
Syarikat minyak itu juga mengekalkan kedudukan sebagai Syarikat Minyak Negara Asia Tenggara Terbaik tahunan buat kali ketiga berturut-turut, menewaskan PT Pertamina Indonesia dan PTT Exploration and Production Thailand.
Naib Presiden Kanan Pembangunan dan Pengeluaran, Perniagaan Huluan, Petronas, Adif Zulkifli menerima anugerah itu bagi pihak syarikat minyak milik negara itu.


“Anugerah ini mengiktiraf dan menghargai semua pihak dalam banyak pasukan yang terlibat dalam PETRONAS secara menyeluruh.
“Usaha semua pihak yang tidak kenal penat, serta komitmen rakan kongsi kami, selain inisiatif usaha sama yang berjaya, membolehkan kejayaan ini diraih,” katanya dalam ucapan.
Majlis Anugerah ini berlangsung sempena Majlis Makan Malam Anugerah Tenaga Asia Pasifik, yang diadakan sempena Perhimpunan Tenaga Asia Pasifik 2019.
Anugerah Majlis Tenaga merupakan penanda aras kecemerlangan global bagi mereka yang bekerja dalam industri minyak dan gas.
Anugerah Majlis menghargai dan mengiktiraf mereka yang terlibat secara langsung dalam industri dalam tempoh 12 bulan lepas.
Lebih 50 hakim meneliti senarai panjang pencalonan selama beberapa minggu untuk memutuskan pemenang, berdasarkan kriteria yang ketat.
“Sejak awal penubuhan kira-kira 45 tahun lepas, PETRONAS telah, dan terus komited dalam misi kami untuk membangun dan menambah nilai kepada sumber minyak dan gas.
“Kami berusaha untuk memberikan kecemerlangan komersial dan operasi selain memperkaya kehidupan pelanggan kami melalui perniagaan bersepadu, sentiasa mengenal pasti berdasarkan sudut pandangan para pelanggan,” kata Adif.
Petronas juga memenangi Kategori Hiliran manakala Naib Presiden Penerokaan Huluan, Emeliana Rice-Oxley, memenangi Anugerah Eksekutif Wanita Terbaik Asia Pasifik.
Sebanyak 10 kategori anugerah kali ini dengan syarikat minyak dan gas Malaysia memenangi empat daripadanya.
Selain Petronas, penyedia perkhidmatan minyak dan gas, Sapura Energy Bhd, turut menerima anugerah Syarikat Asia Pasifik Terbaik dalam perkhidmatan tenaga, kategori luar pesisir dan marin.

cleaned_content: Petroliam Nasional Bhd (PETRONAS) memenangi tiga anugerah pada majlis Anugerah Tenaga Asia Pasifik bagi Majlis Tenaga, pada Rabu. Syarikat minyak itu juga mengekalkan kedudukan sebagai Syarikat Minyak Negara Asia Tenggara Terbaik tahunan buat kali ketiga berturut-turut, menewaskan PT Pertamina Indonesia dan PTT Exploration and Production Thailand. Naib Presiden Kanan Pembangunan dan Pengeluaran, Perniagaan Huluan, Petronas, Adif Zulkifli menerima anugerah itu bagi pihak syarikat minyak milik negara itu. "Anugerah ini mengiktiraf dan menghargai semua pihak dalam banyak pasukan yang terlibat dalam PETRONAS secara menyeluruh. "Usaha semua pihak yang tidak kenal penat, serta komitmen rakan kongsi kami, selain inisiatif usaha sama yang berjaya, membolehkan kejayaan ini diraih," katanya dalam ucapan. Majlis Anugerah ini berlangsung sempena Majlis Makan Malam Anugerah Tenaga Asia Pasifik, yang diadakan sempena Perhimpunan Tenaga Asia Pasifik 2019. Anugerah Majlis Tenaga merupakan penanda aras kecemerlangan global bagi mereka yang bekerja dalam industri minyak dan gas. Anugerah Majlis menghargai dan mengiktiraf mereka yang terlibat secara langsung dalam industri dalam tempoh 12 bulan lepas. Lebih 50 hakim meneliti senarai panjang pencalonan selama beberapa minggu untuk memutuskan pemenang, berdasarkan kriteria yang ketat. "Sejak awal penubuhan kira-kira 45 tahun lepas, PETRONAS telah, dan terus komited dalam misi kami untuk membangun dan menambah nilai kepada sumber minyak dan gas. "Kami berusaha untuk memberikan kecemerlangan komersial dan operasi selain memperkaya kehidupan pelanggan kami melalui perniagaan bersepadu, sentiasa mengenal pasti berdasarkan sudut pandangan para pelanggan," kata Adif. quote: Sabah DAP is happy with the cooperation under the leadership of Mohd Shafie to ensure Sabahans enjoy better livelihood.
content:
KOTA KINABALU: Sabah DAP chairman, Datuk Stephen Wong Tien Fatt describes Chief Minister Datuk Seri Mohd Shafie Apdal as a far-sighted leader with the interests of people at heart when he insisted on maintaining the present political landscape of Sabah.
Therefore, Wong who is also the State Health and People’s Wellbeing Minister said Sabah DAP supported the stand of Mohd Shafie that Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (Bersatu) did not spread its wings to the state.
“Sabah DAP is happy with the cooperation under the leadership of Mohd Shafie to ensure Sabahans enjoy better livelihood.
“Under his leadership, the Sabah state government is now working towards putting Sabah back on the right track,” he said in a statement here.
Wong, the MP for Sandakan said Mohd Shafie is a leaders who practise moderation and tolerance as well as fostering unity and harmony among the various races in the state.
On that factor, he is also confident Sabah will progress and achieve success under the leadership of Mohd Shafie.
